utterances: So, a very long to-do list and the clock is a-ticking.
So, what do you expect the House might get to before they adjourn?
At this point, anybody would - everybody thinks they're going to do something on the FISA court, that's the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, the court that approves wiretaps.
Everybody thinks they're going to do something, however much the House of Representatives fights with the White House over that.
Everybody agrees that providing money for the I-35 bridge span collapse in Minnesota is going to happen.
Funding the Defense Department and passing an energy bill at this point is up in the air.
And when will be done is anybody's guess.
I mean, it could be tomorrow night, Monday, who knows?
But, you know, what's clear, Michele, is that each side right now, each party is making a play for the narrative here, the story that will be told about how this Congress operated this summer.
Democrats would like to go home for their August recess saying, look at all this important work we've done.
Republicans would like to go home saying, look how fouled up the House is.
That was NPR congressional correspondent Andrea Seabrook.
Thank you, Andrea.
You're welcome.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
President Bush has wasted no time in naming a replacement for former Central Intelligence Agency Director Porter Goss.
This morning, the President nominated Air Force General Michael Hayden to run the CIA.
General Hayden has a long intelligence resume and is now number two to John Negroponte, the National Director of Intelligence.
But his selection has drawn immediate criticism.
That criticism has come from Democrats and Republicans in Congress who say the CIA should have a civilian leader, not a general.
There are also concerns that Hayden has overseen a controversial domestic spying program as Director of the National Security Agency.
We'll hear from Capitol Hill in just a few minutes.
First, to NPR's Don Gonyea at the White House.

In the Oval Office this morning, the same room where President Bush accepted Porter Goss's resignation less than three days earlier, the president praised General Hayden as supremely qualified to take over the CIA.
Mike knows our intelligence community from the ground up.
He has been both a provider and a consumer of intelligence.
He's overseen the development of both human and technological intelligence.
He has demonstrated an ability to adapt our intelligence services to the new challenges in the war on terror.
He's the right man to lead the CIA at this critical moment in our nation's history.
Hayden, dressed in his blue Air Force uniform, stood next to the president while Mr. Bush reminded the Senate it had unanimously confirmed the general for his current post just one year ago.
The president called for a speedy confirmation process for the CIA job as well and in his own brief remarks Hayden also looked to Capitol Hill.
In the confirmation process I look forward to meeting with the leaders of the Congress, better understanding their concerns and working with them to move the American intelligence community forward.
This is simply too important not to get absolutely right.
In Hayden, the president has someone who is close to National Intelligence Director John Negroponte, the man who now has jurisdiction over all U.S.
intelligence operations.
Porter Goss left the CIA post, at least in part, because he had conflicts with Negroponte.
The White House anticipates no such issues with Hayden running the agency.
Negroponte held a news conference to discuss Hayden's selection today.
He was asked about concerns that it's not a good idea to have a general as CIA director.

I would respond they should look at the qualifications and I think they can also be assured that Mike Hayden is a very, very independent minded person, blunt spoken, and who I don't think will have any difficulty whatsoever staking out positions that are independent and responsive to the needs of our civilian intelligence community.
Negroponte also addressed General Hayden's connection to the domestic eavesdropping program under which the NSA wiretaps Americans without obtaining a warrant, either before or after the fact.
The administration calls it a terrorist surveillance program, maintaining that it's legal to bypass the special court set up in the 1970s to monitor such activity by intelligence services.

So I think we, it'd be fair to say that we expect quite a bit of questioning about this issue, but I believe that General Hayden will be very, very well-equipped and very well-prepared to answer any questions that might arise.

The fight over the domestic spying program is likely to be the biggest issue in Hayden's confirmation, but it may be one the administration is looking forward to, even though the president's public approval ratings are at their lowest level ever, 31% in the Gallup Poll released today.
The White House would welcome the opportunity to shift the national discussion to steps it has taken in the name of catching terrorists.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, the White House.
Senate Republicans' plan to overhaul the Affordable Care Act could allow states to redefine what is covered by health insurance, and that could mean returning to the days of lifetime limits.
Those were caps on how much insurers might have paid for certain expensive patients.
Alex Olgin from member station WFAE introduces us to a 6-year-old who this bill might affect.
These days, 6-year-old Clara Hardy's biggest struggle is holding her breath long enough to touch the bottom of the neighborhood pool.
OK, ready, Dad?
(Laughter) OK.
But immediately after she was born in 2011, she couldn't even breathe.
She had a serious birth defect called a congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
As she explains it...
On day eight, the surgeons cut me open.
Everything that was in my chest got back to my belly.
They put a patch to fix the hole in my diaphragm.
Well, I think for you and I, that's a reality.
I could take you to sections right here in DC where I've grown up and show you that type of poverty that exists.

What happened, I think, that for the first time for many Americans, it was their first exposure to understand that these problems are not problems that simply exist in Africa and Latin America and places around the world, but actually are here in America.

And this president has been committed to finding solutions that address the root causes of that, namely, the lack of good education, the lack of training for 21st-century jobs, and not having--in our communities, for example, having banks at which you can go to and have money invested, whether it's from your week-to-week paycheck or something else, but that you have these resources right there where you live.
And so you're right.
This has been a problem persistent.

The president made a commitment that we would not rebuild that region without taking into consideration the past history of the region, but also recognizing that we have an opportunity to do it differently.
You know, again, this president has worked hard.
The economy has created more than 1.9 millions jobs over the past 12 months.
Again, many of those--many of our people are getting those jobs.
Are there enough of them?
No. Not enough of our people are getting those jobs, partly because we need to have the skills, we need to have the tools to do that.
And so we are trying to fashion policies that benefit our community while benefiting all of America at the same time.
Claude, have you advised, and if you have, give me the response from the president as to the outreach to black America?
We've had Ken Mehlman on this program.
We know the RNC is attempting to do that, yet we don't see the kind of outreach that I think most African-Americans want to see, particularly considering the poll numbers for this president.
Well, the president has taken opportunities to do just that.
I mean, he meets here.
He's met with African-American leaders, and that's not always publicized.
And again, our president believes that he's the president of all the people, and he is not trying to exploit by advertising who he's meeting with.

But, for example, I traveled with the president to Michigan when he--I'm sorry, to Indianapolis, to the Indianapolis Expo, where he spoke about these very issues we're talking about, and that is the ownership society.
How do we make it so that African-Americans can fully participate in the prosperity of this country and not just some but all have the opportunity to do so as they choose to?
And so these are issues that we're focusing on.
We will continue outreach efforts.
You know, this administration, this president has had more African-Americans in his administration than any other administration prior to this one.
Would it be fair to suggest, though, that there is a hesitancy, if not on his part, certainly by his handlers, to be careful in what areas he chooses?

We know the highly publicized question of the invitation to the NAACP conventions, but there have been others: those of us in the media who have on countless occasions attempted to talk with this president and have continued to be denied and other instances like that.
Well, I'm not quite sure when you say others who've attempted to talk to the president have been denied.
I'm not aware of that.
But I can tell you that the president's met several times with Bruce Gordon, for example, the current head of the NAACP.
So I don't want to get into the discussion of whether he goes to the conference or not.

You know, those issues come up, and again, there are differences sometimes between leaderships of organizations and the fact that the president still chooses to reach out and to promote policies that benefit African-Americans.
That's the message we're going to continue to communicate.
I know that on my part, as the president's chief domestic policy adviser, I welcome and listen to and engage and work with leaders from all communities.
I regularly talk with members of the Congressional Black Caucus.
I work very closely with African-American leaders in the communities at the state and local level.
I work very closely with, again, our faith community leaders.
Why?

Because the president has set a very high standard that we be open to and working with all Americans because regardless of whether they supported him in the 2004 election in large numbers or large degree, he still represents them as their president.
Here's two examples of where I believe this president has made a difference in elevating issues that particularly impact our community.
One of them, again, is the education issue.
As I mentioned, the president's policies have benefited African-Americans disproportionately, which means we've closed the gap more with our white counterparts.
Secondly, an area that has had significant impact on our community is HIV-AIDS.
This president has raised and elevated the issue that is plaguing our community, a health issue that many don't want to talk about.
And the president's calling for this government to commit resources that are going to go after that problem that's tearing our families apart.
And then the last area I would point out is in the area of criminal justice, where we do have so many of our African-American men and women who are incarcerated.
That has had a heavy toll on our community as it relates to providing leadership, providing fathers in the community that could help our young men have good role models.
We have initiatives that we're focusing on that to benefit our community as well.
Claude Allen, domestic policy adviser to the president, we thank you so much for your time today.
Thank you.
Great to be with you.
This is NPR News.
Well, what the House did, as you said, it lifted a nine-year-old ban that had prevented D.C.
from using its own tax dollars on needle exchange programs.
There's a federal ban that is in effect for any jurisdiction in the country, and that remains.
But the city has been the only jurisdiction in the United States that Congress has said could not use its own money to support programs - needle exchange programs of any kind.
So the bill now goes to the Senate, and what are the prospects there?
But after many procedures that Christie says cost more than a million dollars, she finally got to cradle her baby.
C.
HARDY: She was born two months before I turned 30, and we held her for the first time on the day before my 30th birthday.
At the time, she had health insurance through her job as a public school teacher.
So the family's out-of-pocket costs were just $10,000.
But under the GOP proposal, the Hardys could be on the hook for a lot more.
The bill gives states wiggle room on Obamacare's essential health benefits, and that leaves the door open to insurers to charge more and even bring back lifetime caps on how much they'd pay.
The details are up in the air, but Clara's dad, Robert, is worried.
R.
HARDY: I don't really know what that limit would be, but there's a very good chance that she's probably already hit it.
The Affordable Care Act bans insurers from imposing lifetime caps on expensive patients.
Matt Fiedler is with the Brookings Institution.

He warns that if the GOP bill passes, the problem of lifetime limits could spread quickly because large companies that offer health insurance could choose the essential health benefits from whatever state they want.

If you are an employer with, say, 150 employees - so you're buying large, group market coverage; you're entirely in Pennsylvania - you can choose Mississippi's definition of essential health benefits for the purposes of the lifetime limit provision.
For people buying plans from the exchanges, they're likely limited to what their state is willing to cover, says Fiedler.
If a benefit were no longer a central health benefit, you would probably not have plans that offered that type of coverage without an annual or lifetime limit.
So it's just - people would just have no place to go.
And that effectively guts protections for pre-existing conditions.
The Hardys now got insurance through the exchange which they got despite Clara's past health problems.
But Robert Hardy is worried that he may end up footing a substantial portion of future medical expenses Clara could incur because of her past health problem.
